gettingStarted.title: Getting Started
gettingStarted.welcome: Welcome to Dployr! With this platform you can easily deploy and manage web projects.

steps.create: Create a project: Go to Projects → New Project
steps.method: Choose a method: Git repository, ZIP upload or empty template
steps.start: Start the project: Click "Start" in the project view
steps.access: Access it: Your project runs under http://SERVER-IP:PORT

gettingStarted.tip: Tip: For Git projects the project type is automatically detected!

projects.title: Projects
projects.createIntro: There are three ways to create a project:

git.title: Git Repository
git.desc: Clone a repository from GitHub, GitLab, etc.

zip.title: ZIP Upload
zip.desc: Upload a ZIP file with your project.

actions.start: Starts all containers of the project
actions.restart: Restarts the containers (e.g. after code changes)

projectTypes.title: Project Types

static.name: Static
static.desc: HTML, CSS, JavaScript – served with Nginx

php.name: PHP
php.desc: PHP 8.2 with Apache, PDO, GD, mbstring, intl

laravel.name: Laravel/Symfony
laravel.desc: PHP frameworks with Composer and Artisan

nodejsStatic.name: React/Vue/Svelte/Astro
nodejsStatic.desc: Frontend apps built into static files
nodejsStatic.detect: react, vue, svelte, astro in package.json

projectTypes.typeDetectionNote: Type detection: If the wrong type was detected, you can change it in the project settings.

git.title: Git Integration

connectSteps.token: For private repos: Add an access token
connectSteps.clone: The repository will be automatically cloned

git.privateIntro: For private repos you need a personal access token:

privateProviders.github: GitHub: Settings → Developer settings → Personal access tokens

git.privateNote: The token is stored securely and used for pull operations.

actions.pull: Pull the latest changes from remote
actions.deploy: Pull + restart containers in one step

autoDeploy.title: Auto‑Deploy
autoDeploy.intro: Auto‑Deploy automatically updates your project when new commits are pushed. There are two methods: Polling and Webhooks.
autoDeploy.pollingDesc: The server periodically checks the repository for new commits.

pollingHowItWorks.check: Dployr periodically checks the repository (configurable: 5‑60 min)

autoDeploy.webhookDesc: The Git provider notifies Dployr directly on push events – no delay.

webhookHowItWorks.push: You push code to GitHub, GitLab or Bitbucket
webhookHowItWorks.notify: The provider immediately sends a webhook to Dployr
webhookHowItWorks.deploy: Dployr automatically performs pull + container restart

webhookSetupSteps.enable: In the project view under "Git" enable the webhook
webhookSetupSteps.copy: Copy webhook URL and secret (secret is only shown once!)
webhookSetupSteps.provider: Create a webhook at your Git provider (GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket)
webhookSetupSteps.paste: Enter URL and secret, enable push events

autoDeploy.comparisonPolling: Polling: Easy to set up, but delay depends on interval (5‑60 min)
autoDeploy.comparisonWebhook: Webhook: Instant deployment, but requires configuration at Git provider
autoDeploy.note: Note: Both methods are independent and can be used individually or together. Only the project owner can configure them.

databases.title: Databases

postgresql.name: PostgreSQL
postgresql.desc: Advanced features, ideal for complex applications

databases.createNote: Login credentials are automatically generated and stored.
databases.connectIntro: To allow your application to access the database, the credentials must be added to the .env file of your project.

connectSteps.goto: Go to the project view and scroll to "Environment Variables"
connectSteps.select: Choose one of your databases from the dropdown
connectSteps.auto: The credentials are automatically written into .env
connectSteps.restart: Restart the container so the changes take effect

databases.backgroundIntro: When clicking "Set up DB" the system performs the following steps:

backgroundSteps.template: Load template: If a .env.example exists, it is used as base
backgroundSteps.detect: Detect variables: The system searches the file for known database variable names
backgroundSteps.replace: Replace values: Found DB variables are replaced with correct Dployr credentials
backgroundSteps.append: Add missing: Credentials not found are appended at end of file
backgroundSteps.keep: Keep others: All other variables (API keys, app settings, etc.) remain unchanged

databases.variablesIntro: The system automatically recognizes various spellings for database credentials:
databases.exampleBefore: Assume your project has the following .env.example:
databases.exampleAfter: After selecting your database, the .env becomes:
databases.exampleNote: App variables remain unchanged; only DB variables are replaced.
databases.tipEnvExample: Tip: If your project has a .env.example, it is automatically used as template. You do not need to copy it manually!
databases.noteRestart: Important: After setting up the database you must restart the container so the application loads the new environment variables.
databases.noteButton: The button only appears once you have created at least one database. You can also edit the .env file manually in the editor anytime.

sharing.title: Project Sharing
sharing.intro: Share projects with other users and manage their permissions.
sharing.ownerOnly: Only the owner can: delete project, disconnect Git connection, configure Auto‑Deploy, manage shares

workspaces.title: Workspaces
workspaces.intro: Workspaces are cloud-based development environments right in your browser. You can edit your code in a full IDE without installing any local tools.

features.ide: Full IDE (VS Code) in the browser
features.apiKeys: Secure storage of API keys (Anthropic, OpenAI, etc.)

createSteps.wait: Wait until the container has started
createSteps.open: The IDE opens automatically in the browser

workspaces.ideIntro: The workspace IDE is based on VS Code and offers:

ideFeatures.editor: Code editor with syntax highlighting for all common languages
ideFeatures.explorer: File explorer to navigate the project
ideFeatures.terminal: Integrated terminal for commands (npm, git, etc.)
ideFeatures.search: Global search across the entire project

workspaces.terminalIntro: Through the terminal you can execute commands directly in the container:

terminalExamples.npm: npm install / npm run dev - Node.js commands
terminalExamples.git: git status / git pull - Git operations

workspaces.apiKeysIntro: You can securely store API keys for AI assistants like Claude Code in your workspace:

apiKeysSteps.use: The key is automatically available as an environment variable

workspaces.apiKeysNote: Note: API keys are encrypted with AES-256-GCM and are only available inside the workspace container.
workspaces.syncIntro: Changes in the workspace are automatically synchronized with your project:

syncFeatures.manual: Manual sync via the "Sync" button available
syncFeatures.rebuild: "Rebuild" option to recreate the container if problems occur

statusTypes.stopped: Stopped: Workspace is inactive, files are preserved
statusTypes.running: Running: Workspace is active and can be used
statusTypes.error: Error: Problem during startup, check the logs

workspaces.note: Tip: Workspaces are automatically stopped after 30 minutes of inactivity to save resources. Your changes are preserved.

domains.title: Domains & SSL
domains.intro: Connect custom domains to your projects and secure them with free SSL certificates from Let's Encrypt.

howTo.open: Open the project view of your project
howTo.add: Click "Add" – the domain is immediately available

prerequisites.dns: DNS configured: The domain must point to the server IP (A record)
prerequisites.running: Project running: The container must be started
prerequisites.permission: Permission: You must be owner or have "Full Access"

domains.sslDesc: SSL certificates are automatically requested via Let's Encrypt. The certificate is renewed automatically before expiration. After activation your project is accessible via HTTPS.
domains.note: Tip: The domain feature only appears when the administrator has enabled NPM.
domains.dnsWarning: Important: Make sure your domain points to this server before adding it. Otherwise SSL certificate creation will fail.

notifications.title: Email Notifications
notifications.intro: Dployr can notify you via email about important events. This feature must be enabled by the administrator.

verification.name: Email Verification
verification.desc: After registration you receive an email to confirm your email address.

passwordReset.name: Password Reset
passwordReset.desc: If you forgot your password, you can request a reset link.

approval.name: Account Approval
approval.desc: You will be notified when an administrator has approved your account.

deploySuccess.name: Deployment Successful
deploySuccess.desc: Notification after successful deployment (pull, auto-deploy, webhook).

deployFailure.name: Deployment Failed
deployFailure.desc: Immediate notification when a deployment fails.

notifications.settingsIntro: You can choose which notifications you want to receive:

settingsSteps.goto: Click on your username in the top right
settingsSteps.toggle: Enable or disable the desired notification types

requirements.verified: Your email address must be verified
requirements.address: You must have an email address on file

notifications.note: Note: If you haven't added or verified an email address yet, you can do so in the notification settings.

security.title: Security
security.intro: Protect your account with additional security measures.
security.twofaIntro: 2FA adds an extra layer of security to your account. In addition to your password, you need a time-based code from an authenticator app.

twofaSetupSteps.scan: Scan the QR code with an authenticator app (Google Authenticator, Authy, etc.)
twofaSetupSteps.enter: Enter the 6-digit code from the app
twofaSetupSteps.save: Save the backup codes in a secure location

security.backupCodesIntro: When activating 2FA, you receive 10 backup codes. These can be used if you don't have access to your authenticator app.

backupCodesFeatures.oneTime: Each code can only be used once
backupCodesFeatures.store: Store them securely (password manager, print them)
backupCodesFeatures.regenerate: You can generate new codes in the security settings

security.backupCodesWarning: Important: If you've used all backup codes and lose your authenticator app, access to your account is only possible through the administrator.

twofaLoginSteps.password: Log in as usual with username and password
twofaLoginSteps.code: Enter the 6-digit code from your authenticator app
twofaLoginSteps.backup: If needed: Use a backup code instead

security.twofaNote: Note: After deactivation, your account is only protected by your password. It is recommended to keep 2FA enabled.

admin.title: Administration

userManagementActions.approve: Approve registrations: New users must be approved by an admin
userManagementActions.manage: Manage users: change rights, delete users
userManagementActions.adminRights: Grant admin rights: make other users admins

admin.pendingDesc: In the admin area you see all pending registrations and can approve or reject them.
admin.npmIntro: Nginx Proxy Manager (NPM) enables domain management and SSL certificates for projects:

npmFeatures.enable: Enable/disable NPM: The NPM container is controlled from the dashboard
npmFeatures.credentials: Configure credentials: Email and password for NPM admin and Let's Encrypt
npmFeatures.ports: Adjust ports: HTTP (80), HTTPS (443) and Admin (81) can be changed
npmFeatures.initialize: Initialize: Changes default credentials (admin@example.com) to your configured ones
npmFeatures.logs: Container logs: Live view of NPM logs for debugging

admin.npmNote: Note: After first start and initialization, you can access the NPM panel via the "Open Panel" button.
admin.emailSetup: Setup: Under Admin → Email Settings you can configure SMTP credentials and test the connection.
admin.emailNote: Note: Email is optional. Without email configuration the platform still works, but without the features mentioned above.

notStarting.q: My project won't start – what do I do?

a.logs: Check the logs for error messages
a.type: Ensure the project type is correct
a.env: Check the .env file for missing variables
a.nodejs: For Node.js: Is there a package.json with a start script?

database.q: How do I connect my app to the database?

a.click: Click DB setup and choose a database
a.auto: Credentials are intelligently inserted into your .env

database.tip: Tip: If your project has a .env.example with different variable names (e.g. DB_USER instead of DB_USERNAME), they are automatically detected and replaced!

changes.q: Why don't I see my changes?

a.git: Git projects: Did you run a pull?
a.restart: After pull: update containers with restart
a.cache: Browser cache: try a hard refresh (Ctrl+Shift+R)

access.q: How do I reach my project from outside?
access.a: Each project gets its own port. The URL is: http://<SERVER-IP>:<PORT>. Find the port in the project details.

ssh.q: Can I SSH/SFTP into my project?

a.intro: Currently no direct SSH/SFTP access is offered. Options:
a.git: Git: push changes via Git repository
a.zip: ZIP upload: upload files as ZIP
a.env: .env editor: edit environment variables directly in the dashboard

docker.q: Can I use custom docker-compose.yml files?

a.intro: Yes! Dployr supports custom docker-compose.yml files for multi-container projects.
a.howto: Place a docker-compose.yml in the root of your Git repository. Dployr will automatically detect it.
a.transforms: Dployr applies automatic adjustments: container names are prefixed with your username, ports are remapped to available external ports, all services receive resource limits.
a.supported: Supported: web servers (Nginx, Apache), databases (MySQL, PostgreSQL, MongoDB, Redis), build tools and custom images.
a.security: Security restrictions: no privileged containers, no host network mode, no Docker socket mounts, no access to system directories.
